pullRequest.body:
We added some lemmas of fixed points of function `f` with `f(x) >= x`, where `f : α → α` is a function on a finite type `α`. This will be needed in proof of Bondy-Chvátal theorem.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

See also branch `meow-sister/BondyChvatal`.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [5ad2829b44](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15578/commits/5ad2829b449b90f5623b1a8bac9484addd0880dd)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Dynamics.FixedPoints.Increasing`|605|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Monotone.eventuallyConst_atTop`
`+ eventualValue`
`+ eventuallyConst_iterate_of_wellFoundedGT`
`+ isFixedPt_eventualValue`
`+ iterate_fixed_point_from_index`
`+ selfIncreasingFixedPointIndex`
`+ selfIncreasingFixedPointIndex_spec`
`+ self_le_eventualValue`
`+ stabilizationIndex`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
@b-mehta and I discussed this PR and we basically think the right setup is Scott continuity, rather than what you currently have.

> @b-mehta and I discussed this PR and we basically think the right setup is Scott continuity, rather than what you currently have.

What does this mean for this PR?

It is saying that we are refusing the PR in its current form and would like to see everything rewritten in terms of `ScottContinuous` (or related) and theorems like https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/4b83244f3ea8cf1ebc70f68bc5b94691e826c827/Mathlib/Order/OmegaCompletePartialOrder.lean#L977-L979

This looks almost identical to the setup for normal ordinal functions! Specifically, any normal function satisfies `x ≤ f x`, and for any `a`, the supremum of `f^[n] a` is a fixed point of `f`. We have this as [`Ordinal.nfp`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Ordinal/FixedPoint.html#Ordinal.nfp).

I don't know anything about Scott continuity, but if there's anything that can be done to merge our results together, I'd be glad to learn.
I suggest you read `Order.OmegaCompletePartialOrder`. It's very instructive! Gabriel sorted out a bunch of things there which are underused in the rest of mathlib.

@znssong, isn't the content of this PR basically superseded by [`monotonicSequenceLimitIndex`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/OrderIsoNat.html#monotonicSequenceLimitIndex)?
We already have [Function.IsFixedPt.iterate](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Dynamics/FixedPoints/Basic.html#Function.IsFixedPt.iterate)

Please don't use `variable` for assumptions, just for variables. Also, if you don't need `Fintype` to **state** a theorem, then please assume `[Finite α]` and do `cases nonempty_fintype α`, if you need `Fintype α` in the proof.
This lemma doesn't need `hf` or `Fintype α`, so please move it to `Basic`.

We have [Monotone.monotone_iterate_of_le_map](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Iterate.html#Monotone.monotone_iterate_of_le_map) UPD: it's not exactly the same, but it makes sense to add your lemma in that file. UPD: [Function.monotone_iterate_of_id_le](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Iterate.html#Function.monotone_iterate_of_id_le) is exactly this lemma (found by https://loogle.lean-lang.org/?q=Monotone%2C+Nat.iterate )

This theorem is not specific to iterations. It works for any monotone function on a type with well founded `>` relation. BTW, you can use [Filter.EventuallyConst](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/EventuallyConst.html#Filter.EventuallyConst) to formulate the theorem.
See `Nat.le_induction` or [monotone_nat_of_le_succ](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Monotone/Basic.html#monotone_nat_of_le_succ)
Now everything has been fixed, and I've added your name to the list of authors to express my gratitude for your help.

Some cheeky little golfing:
```suggestion
  rw [eventuallyConst_atTop]
  obtain ⟨x, hx⟩ : ∃ x, g x = _ := hα.wf.min_mem _ (Set.range_nonempty _)
  exact ⟨x, fun z hz =>
    (hg hz).eq_of_not_gt (hx ▸ hα.wf.not_lt_min _ _ (Set.mem_range_self _))⟩
```

```suggestion
/-- The function `g : ι → α` will eventually be constant if the `>` relation on `α` is well-founded. -/
```
Could a version for `<` potentially be useful?

I don't think any part of the file actually requires finitude, only the well-foundedness condition. Note that we have [`Finite.wellFounded_of_trans_of_irrefl`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Fintype/Card.html#Finite.wellFounded_of_trans_of_irrefl).
We have `Finite.to_wellFoundedGT`.
That's even better.

```suggestion
/-- Iterations of an inflationary endomorphisms of a cowell-founded order eventually stabilise. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma eventuallyConst_iterate_of_wellFoundedGT (hf : id ≤ f) (x : α) :
```
That's too generic of a name
That's incorrect. It's not THE index at which your sequence becomes constant, but merely AN index from which your sequence becomes constant
This generalises to `EventuallyConst` sequences
For general `EventuallyConst`, you can just use `eventuallyConst_atTop.mp` and `Exists.choose`.
I mean, yes. For your use case as well. I don't see why your use case should get a particular treatment compared to other use cases
OK, I changed.
Please don't use \ge but instead \le

```suggestion
lemma isFixedPt_eventualValue (hf : id ≤ f) (x : α) : IsFixedPt f (eventualValue hf x) := by
```

```suggestion
lemma selfIncreasingFixedPointIndex_spec (hf : id ≤ f) (x : α) :
```

```suggestion
  conv_lhs => rw [← iterate_zero_apply f x]
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Function): Fixed points of function `f` with `f(x) >= x`
